awd_titl_txt: L-functions, Fourier Transforms, and Gamma Factors
awd_abstract_narration:
An important goal in any mathematical theory is to understand one set of objects by means of another one. When the two sets are in a one-to-one correspondence, then one may call the correspondence a reciprocity law. One deep example of a reciprocity law is that of Artin and Langlands, which is a vast generalization of Quadratic Reciprocity Law discovered by Gauss that is important for solving equations over the integers modulo a prime, and which is the genesis of the more general Langlands Program. While a general reciprocity law within the Langlands program is still far from properly formulated, even for objects over rational numbers, one can consider the "Langlands Functoriality Principle," which is a consequence of Artin-Langlands reciprocity and is a conjecture that is currently at the core of Langlands program. This project deals with both reciprocity and functoriality and will establish new techniques and tools to study them.

In more detail, the PI will compare the Fourier transform defined by Braverman-Kazhdan and the Hankel transform defined by Ngo, for the standard L-functions for classical groups. In the long run this will lead to a full theory of L-functions for cusp forms on any reductive group and any irreducible representation of its L-group. This will not only lead to fairly general cases of functoriality through converse theorems, but will also provide suitable Poisson summation formulas that are needed in the Beyond Endoscopy approach to functoriality. In terms of reciprocity, a number of cases where the equality of Artin factors with the factors defined by the Langlands-Shahidi method through the local Langlands correspondence (local reciprocity) for GL(n) will be established, following the techniques used in the cases of exterior and symmetric square factors for GL(n) proved earlier. Projects involving p-adic L-functions, local coefficients matrices for covering groups, and Rankin products of L-functions for GSpin groups will also be pursued.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the term of this award the following results were obtained. Among them was the study of new generalized Fourier transforms needed for the developement of a general theory of L-functions within the Langlands program. This theory generalizes Tate-Godement-Jacquet's approach in the cases of general linear groups to the arbitray reductive groups. Among the ingredients in the theory are gamma factors which are needed for functional equations, an important component of the theory. In a joint paper with my student, William Sokurski, published in the Journal of Number Theory, we established the multiplicativity of these factors in general but under suitable working hypothesis for these factors. The remaining results constituted Sokurski's thesis who is now a postdoc at the University of Toronto. These are parts of the new program initiated by Braverman-Kazhdan/Ngo. The second project was a joint work with my former postdocs Fan Gao and Dani Szpruch during which we addressed several questions concerning covering groups. In particular, we addressed the lack of multiplicity one for their Whittaker functionals by introducing "local coefficients matrices" among other things. This is a long 116-page paper which is now accepted to appear as a monograph in the Memoirs of AMS. Our second paper which is as long as the other one answers the issues of restrictions of representations and the study of their R-groups. This paper is now submitted and is under review. The project on p-adic L-functions was performed by my student, Razan Taha, who has successfully extended the work by Gelbart-Miller-Panchishkin-Shahidi from Q to totally real fields following Deligne-Ribet theory of these p-adic L-functions, relating inverses of these L-functions to non-constant Fourier coefficients of suitable Eisenstein series. Her thesis is now accepted for publication. Finally as a new project, the investigator has been studying as a joint work with Baiying Liu, the local Jiang's conjecture for classical groups. This is a conjecture which generalizes a conjecture of the investigator on the existence of representations with Whittaker models in every tempered L-packet to local Arthur packets which treat non-tempered representations. It predicts what the wave front sets of their local character expansions via Harish-Chandra/Howe must be. 

During the term of this award, the investigator has graduated 4 students(two domestic and one woman) and have been advising or co-advising another 4 students (two demestic). I have also been teaching advanced and qualifying courses in our department and been mentor to one faculty and one postdoc. These courses are foundational in number theory and with Purdue's Algebra/Number Theory/Algebraic Geometry group's recent high ranking (15th with Cornall) by US News, is bound to attract more students to number theory and arithmetic geometry within the Langlands Program, where our strength lies.
